{{refimprove|date=August 2016}}
The '''Shanghai Project''' is a multidisciplinary ideas platform bringing together practitioners from a variety of disciplines, including art, architecture, design, film, performance, sound, as well as the humanities, social and natural sciences.<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.shanghai-project.org/about/|website=Shanghai Project}}</ref>
The inaugural edition of the Shanghai Project, under the co-artistic directorship of [[Yongwoo Lee]], Executive Director of Shanghai Himalayas Museum, and [[Hans Ulrich Obrist]], Artistic Director of [[Serpentine Galleries]] London, is organized by the [[Shanghai Himalayas Museum]], and co-organized by the Shanghai International Culture Association, and supported by [[Envision Energy]] and Zendai Group.<ref>{{cite news|title=A bridge to culture — before the deluge|url=https://www.ft.com/content/428e8b0e-f121-11e5-9f20-c3a047354386|publisher=''[[Financial Times]]''|date=25 March 2016}}</ref>
==History== The Shanghai Project was founded in 2015 by Yongwoo Lee in partnership with Dai Zhikang. The first phase of Shanghai Project took place in 2016 at the Himalaya Center and [[Shanghai Himalayas Museum]], its satellite venue at Zendai Zhujiajiao Art Museum, and various venues across Shanghai including Century Park (Shanghai)|Century Park in Pudong New District.
* 2016: Inaugural edition of Shanghai Project, Envision 2116, Co-Artistic Directors: [[Yongwoo Lee]] and [[Hans Ulrich Obrist]].
==First edition of Shanghai Project (2016)== The inaugural edition of the Shanghai Project will launch on September 4, 2016 and take place over the duration of eleven months, ending in July 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shanghai Project: City’s Newest Art Festival Envisions the Future in 2116|url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1473245/shanghai-project-citys-newest-art-festival-envisions-the|website=BLOUART INFO|publisher=[[Louise Blouin Media]]}}</ref>
Taking “Envision 2116” as its theme, the festival gathering—from China and abroad—"artists, filmmakers, performers, musicians, designers, architects, writers (including journalists, bloggers, science fiction novelists, and poets), philosophers, historians, scientists, economists, geographers, sociologists, anthropologists, doctors, lawyers, engineers, hackers, and activists, all of whom will be dubbed 'researchers'",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.artnet.com/exhibitions/hans-ulrich-obrist-yongwoo-lee-helm-first-edition-mysterious-shanghai-project-460199|title=Hans Ulrich Obrist to Helm First Edition of Mysterious Shanghai Project|last=|first=|date=March 28, 2016|website=[[Artnet]]|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and the people of Shanghai to think, discuss, relate, and act on the sustainability of the humankind's futures in the 22nd century".
Phase one of the first edition includes exhibitions, gatherings, screenings, talks, workshops, an open call, a commissioned architectural pavilion, and public art installations across sites in Shanghai, as well as the annual International Biennial Association Conference in collaboration with the [[Power Station of Art]] from September 3–4, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Project uses art, hands-on activities to ponder big questions|publisher=Shanghai Daily|date=29 July 2016}}</ref>
Researchers of this phase included: [[Xu Bing]],<ref>https://news.artnet.com/exhibitions/on-spectacle-and-sustainability-at-the-shanghai-project-738206</ref> [[Jenova Chen]], [[Otobong Nkanga]], [[Douglas Coupland]], [[Liam Gillick]], Liu Yi, [[Sou Fujimoto]], and [[Cildo Meireles]], etc.<ref>{{cite web|title=Researchers|url=http://www.shanghai-project.org/researchers/|website=Shanghai Project}}</ref>
===Shanghai Project Pavilion=== The Shanghai Project invited Japanese architect [[Sou Fujimoto]] <ref>{{cite news|title=Shanghai Project to explore future of sustainable development|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/m/shanghai/lujiazui/2016-07/28/content_26258559.htm|agency=China Daily|date=July 28, 2016}}</ref> to design and construct a pavilion, titled "Envision Pavilion" and situated besides the [[Arata Isozaki]]-designed Shanghai Himalayas Center, to house various cultural activities and amenities.
===Exhibitions program=== The Shanghai Project's exhibitions program creates multiple narratives in response to the theme of "Envision 2116", through an open and flexible configuration of multi-media installations, taking place at different venues across Shanghai.<ref>{{cite news|title=Project uses art, hands-on activities to ponder big questions|publisher=Shanghai Daily|date=29 July 2016}}</ref>
===Shanghai Project Public Program=== The Shanghai Project’s public program includes a wide range of public activities, including performances, film and video screenings, discursive programs and participatory events. Notable ones include “Community Participation Program,” a series of neighborhood events intended to open a dialogue between the city of Shanghai and its residents that launched on July 15, 2016, joint programs with Jifeng Bookstore and Shanghai Flaneur, as well as a children’s program located in Century Park.
===Qidian, Shanghai Project Open Call=== “Qidian,” which loosely translates into “starting point”, is an nationwide open call designed to tap into the talent and interests of China’s new generation, which is based on the long-term international project “89plus” (co-curated by Simon Castets and Hans Ulrich Obrist in collaboration with Katherine Dionysius).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.shanghai-project.org/ Shanghai Project website]

{{Infobox non-profit | name = Society for Science & the Public | image = | caption = | founder = [[Edward W. Scripps]]
[[William Emerson Ritter]] | type = [[501(c)3]] [[Non-profit organization|Non-profit]] | tax_id = 53-0196483[http://www.societyforscience.org/sslpage.aspx?pid=787 "About Society for Science and the Public,"] Society for Science and the Public. Accessed: January 30, 2013. | registration_id = | founded_date = 1921 | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | coordinates = | origins = | key_people = [[Maya Ajmera]], President and CEO
[[H. Robert Horvitz]], Chairman of the Board | area_served = | products = ''[[Science News]]''
''[https://student.societyforscience.org/sciencenews-students Science News for Students]'' | services = | focus = | mission = "public engagement in scientific research and education"[http://www.societyforscience.org/about "About Society for Science & the Public,"] Society for Science and the Public. Accessed: January 30, 2013. | method = | revenue = $17.1 million (2010)[http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=10079 "Society for Science & the Public,"] Charity Navigator. Accessed: January 30, 2013. | endowment = $96.7 million (2010) | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 60[http://www.societyforscience.org/who "About Us,"] Society for Science and the Public. Accessed: January 30, 2013. | num_members = | motto = ''Inform. Educate. Inspire.'' | former name = Science Service | homepage = {{URL|http://www.societyforscience.org/}} | footnotes = }} [[File:Emma Reh (1896-1982).jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[Emma Reh]] (1896–1982) was a [[science journalist]] for ''Science Service'' in the 1920s and 1930s. Here she is visiting an [[archaeological site]] in [[Oaxaca]].{{cite web |title=Emma Reh (1896-1982) |url=http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_arc_289408 |work=Smithsonian Institution |accessdate=11 July 2013}}]] '''Society for Science & the Public''' ('''SSP'''), formerly known as '''Science Service''', is a [[501(c)3]] [[non-profit organization]] dedicated to the promotion of science, through its [[science education]] programs and [[science communication|publications]], including the bi-weekly ''[[Science News]]'' magazine and the free-accessible online ''Science News for Students''. The organization has headquarters in [[Washington, D.C.]] It promotes the understanding and appreciation of science and the role it plays in human advancement.{{cite web|url=https://www.societyforscience.org/mission-and-history |title=Mission & History |publisher=Society for Science & the Public. societyforscience.org |date= |accessdate=December 17, 2017}} In pursuit of this goal, it publishes ''[[Science News]]'' and ''[[Science News for Students]]'', and sponsors events including the [[Intel International Science and Engineering Fair]], the [[Regeneron Science Talent Search]], and the [[Broadcom MASTERS]] (Math, Applied Science, Technology and Engineering for Rising Stars) competition.[http://www.societyforscience.org/masters The Broadcom MASTERS], Society for Science and the Public. == History == SSP was founded in 1921 by journalist [[Edward W. Scripps]] and zoologist [[William Emerson Ritter]], under the name "Science Service", with the goal of informing the public of the latest scientific discoveries and achievements.Tobey, Ronald C. (1971). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=QTpaQgQVj9AC&pg=PA66 The American Ideology of National Science, 1919-1930]''. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press. {{ISBN|9780822975946}}. pp. 66-70. The Science Service emerged from a reorganization of a group that Scripps and Ritter had originally founded in 1919 as the American Society for the Dissemination of Science. Scripps and Ritter accomplished their goal by distributing the latest science research to the public through a news service for reporters. In 1922, due to interest from non-journalists, Science Service started distributing ''[[Science News-Letter]]'', which became a magazine in 1926. It quickly grew into a prime source of science news for libraries, schools, and individuals. In 1942, Science Service launched the first of its prestigious education competitions, the [[Westinghouse Science Talent Search]]. In 2008, Science Service became Society for Science & the Public (SSP) in order to better reflect the mission of the organization to advocate for science in the public interest.{{cn|date=July 2018}} Between the World Wars, Science Service sponsored [[Science Clubs of America]], founded by [[Watson Davis]], a national organization to popularize science among amateur scientists. High school science clubs were encouraged to join.{{cite journal|title=News and Views: Science Clubs of America|journal=Nature|date=15 November 1941|volume=148|issue=3759|page=590|doi=10.1038/148590a0}} From 1940 through 1989, Science Service sponsored the [[Things of Science]] Club. Subscribers received a monthly box containing some kind or material or artifact along with an pamphlet describing experiments that could be done with it. Sometimes the kits contained parts which could be assembled into a scientific instrument.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1hwiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QKQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4985,4298460&dq=things-of-science&hl=en|title=Thing-of-the-Month Club will provide remarkable objects|last=Othman|first=Frederick C.|date=October 7, 1947|work=San Jose Evening News|accessdate=1 November 2013}} Beginning in 2003, it published ''Science News for Kids'', an online magazine aimed at students, and also at teachers and parents ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.sciencenews.org/ Science News] * [https://student.societyforscience.org/sciencenews-students Science News for Students website] * [http://www.societyforscience.org Science Service, now Society for Science & the Public]. * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/smithsonian/sets/72157624349863362/ Selected images from Science Service files] at the [[Smithsonian Institution]] Archives {{Authority Control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Society For Science And The Public}} [[Category:Society for Science and the Public| ]] [[Category:1921 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]] [[Category:Educational organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Publishing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1921]] [[Category:Science education in the United States]] [[Category:Scientific organizations established in 1921]] [[Category:Science advocacy organizations]]

page.title: The Story of Science in America

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = The Story of Science in America | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Story of Science in America.jpg | caption = Dust jacket from first edition of ''The Story of Science in America'' | author = [[L. Sprague de Camp]] and [[Catherine Crook de Camp]] | illustrator = [[Leonard Everett Fisher]] | cover_artist = [[Leonard Everett Fisher]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[History]], [[Science]] | publisher = [[Charles Scribner's Sons]] | release_date = 1967 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]]) | pages = 282 pp | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Story of Science in America''''' is a 1967 [[science book]] by [[L. Sprague de Camp]] and [[Catherine Crook de Camp]], illustrated by [[Leonard Everett Fisher]], published by [[Charles Scribner's Sons]]. It has been translated into Spanish, [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Burmese language|Burmese]] and French.<ref>{{cite book | last=Laughlin | first=Charlotte |author2=Daniel J. H. Levack | title=De Camp: An L. Sprague de Camp Bibliography | location=San Francisco | publisher=Underwood/Miller | pages=93–94 | year=1983}}</ref>
==Summary== The book traces the work of [[inventor]]s and [[Natural history|naturalist]]s in the United States from the Colonial era through the mid-19th century, and relates scientific developments in the century following.
==Contents== *Part One - Science Comes to America **I - Science in the Colonies **II - Benjamin Franklin's Century **III - American Explorers and Expeditions **IV - The World of Nature **V - Early Inventors and Inventions **VI - The Great Industrial Revolution *Part Two - The Physical Sciences **VII - The Exact Sciences **VIII - The Sky Above **IX - The Earth and its Waters **X - The Revolution in Physics *Part Three - The Biological Sciences **XI - The Sciences of Life **XII - The Most Marvelous Machine **XIII - The Sciences of Man *Part Four - The Applied Sciences **XIV - The Electrical Revolution **XV - The Internal-Combustion Revolution **XVI - The Dangerous Depths of Space **XVII - Scientists of Today and Tomorrow *Notes *Selected Bibliography *Index
==Reception== Critical response to the book was positive. [[Jane Brody|Jane E. Brody]], writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', called it "a fast-moving, informative and thoroughly enjoyable chronicle, with amusing anecdotes, legends and interesting sidelights that reflect the personalities, lives and times of the men who shaped our nation scientifically." She noted that "the authors have kept their writing free of chauvinism," and that "[m]ost of the scientific concepts are well enough explained so that even the newcomer to science should be able to grasp at least the essence of them."<ref>"Science For Teen-Agers," ''New York Times'', November 5, 1967, p. BR216.</ref> In the same issue the book was included among seventy-five recommended titles selected by the Children's Editor of the newspaper's Book Review, described as an "[i]nformative, thoroughly enjoyable chronicle of the development of science in our country."<ref>"Seventy-Five Recommended Titles," ''New York Times'', November 5, 1967, p. BR233.</ref>
''[[Publishers Weekly|Publishers' Weekly]]'' stated that "[t]o read the index ... is to read the names of the men and of their discoveries in science in America, from the earliest days ... to the space age. To read the book is to become familiar with the men and their contributions to science."<ref>"Other Science Topics," ''Publishers' Weekly'', November 13, 1967, p. 80.</ref>
George Basalia, writing for ''[[Library Journal]]'', called the book "a first-rate history of American science and technology for high-school students ... cover[ing] major American technical discoveries as well as our contributions to the purely theoretical aspects of science." He found "much to be praised ... the book is intelligently conceived, carefully organized, clearly written, and handsomely designed. Unfortunately, the illustrations do not do justice to [the] excellent text."<ref>"De CAMP, L. Sprague & Catherine C. De Camp. ''The Story of Science in America''," ''Library Journal'', December 15, 1967, p. 4620.</ref>
H. D. Allen in the ''[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]]'' wrote that the book's story "makes fascinating reading," and that "[w]hile the treatment of any one discipline may at first seem superficial and chatty, the total impact is most impressive, for the reader is left with an acquaintance with the leading figures of the age of science and some appreciation of how the contribution of each influenced a way of life." He concluded "The breadth of scientific knowledge which this book represents is remarkable, as is the skill with which it has been set down and the effortlessness with which it reads."<ref>"Books: Roster Of Science," ''Montreal Gazette'', January 27, 1968, p. 33.</ref>
''[[Booklist|The Booklist]]'' called it "[a] wide-ranging survey [that] reflects the authors' humanistic interests as well as their familiarity with several branches of science and their extensive background reading."<ref>"Books for young adults," ''The Booklist'', February 15, 1968, p. 680.</ref>
[[Hal Clement|Harry C. Stubbs]] in ''[[The Horn Book Magazine]]'' included it among "half a dozen books dealing ... with the history of science [that] I can recommend [both] to nonscientists as guides toward the Light [and] to scientists and science teachers as reminders that what we know was long, slow, and hard in coming." He noted that it "give[s] us a series of fascinating biographical and anecdotal items strung loosely on the thread of developing scientific knowledge."<ref>"Views on Science Books," ''The Horn Book Magazine'', February 1968, pp. 81-83.</ref>
[[Philip Morrison|Philip]] and Phylis Morrison in ''[[Scientific American]]'' felt it "manages to convey a sense of coherence, even though it deals at staccato length with so many men, trends and ideas ... The reason is partly in the expert writing--smooth, unusually candid, cheerful and sometimes a bit condescending (as in the two or three pages about Veblen)." They add that "[n]ot all the dicta of the authors seem reasonable, but to find any personal judgment at work is so rare in this kind of pedagogy that one is pleased by the De Camps even when one disagrees with them."<ref>"A Christmas selection of books on science for younger readers," ''Scientific American'', December 1968, p. 138.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{L. Sprague de Camp}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Story of Science in America, The}} [[Category:1967 books]] [[Category:Science books]] [[Category:Books by L. Sprague de Camp]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox book | name = Theory of the Earth | image = Trans Royal Society of Edinburgh cover.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = The issue of the cover of ''Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh'' that the "Theory of the Earth" was first published | author = [[James Hutton]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Scotland | language = English | series = Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, Vol. 1 | publisher = [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] | pub_date = 1788 }} '''''Theory of the Earth''''' was a publication by [[James Hutton]] which laid the foundations for [[geology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/theory-of-the-earth/#|title=Theory of The Earth|author=Scientific American|accessdate=February 24, 2018}}</ref><ref>Mather, Kirtley & Mason, Shirley L. (eds) [1939] 1967. ''A source book in Geology, 1400–1900''. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 92{{ndash}}100. {{ISBN|0-674-82277-3}}</ref> In it he showed that the Earth is the product of natural forces. What could be seen happening today, over long periods of time, could produce what we see in the rocks. This idea, [[uniformitarianism]], was used by [[Charles Lyell]] in his work, and Lyell's textbook was an important influence on [[Charles Darwin]]. The work was first published in 1788<ref name="Hutton1788">{{cite journal |last1=Hutton |first1=James |author-link1=James Hutton |year=1788 |title=Theory of the Earth; or an Investigation of the Laws observable in the Composition, Dissolution, and Restoration of Land upon the Globe |journal=Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh |publisher=[[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] |volume=1 |issue=Part 2 |pages=209–304 |url=https://archive.org/details/transactionsofro01roya }}</ref> by the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]], and later in 1795 as two book volumes.<ref name="Hutton1795v1">{{cite book |last1=Hutton |first1=James |year=1795 |title=Theory of the Earth |volume=1 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref><ref name="Hutton1795v2">{{cite book |last1=Hutton |first1=James |year=1795 |title=Theory of the Earth |volume=2 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref>
Hutton recognized that rocks record the evidence of the past action of processes which still operate today. He also [[wikt:anticipate|anticipated]] [[natural selection]], as follows: :"Those which depart most from the best adapted constitution, will be the most liable to perish, while, on the other hand, those organised bodies, which most approach to the best constitution for the present circumstances, will be best adapted to continue, in preserving themselves and multiplying the individuals of their race".<ref name="Pearson">{{cite journal |title=In retrospect |author=Pearson, Paul N |year=2003 |journal=Nature |doi=10.1038/425665a}}</ref>
Hutton's [[prose]] hindered his theories.<ref>{{cite book | author = Geikie, Archibald 1897 | title = The founders of geology | page = 166 | publisher = Macmillan| location = London | url = https://books.google.com/?id=xPYLAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA150&dq=james+hutton+geology}}</ref> [[John Playfair]] in 1802 restated of Huttton's geological ideas in clearer English. However, he left out Hutton's thoughts on [[evolution]].<ref>Playfair, John 1802. ''Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth''. Edinburgh. Playfair added an important observation of his own: that [[glacier]]s can transport great quantities of rock.</ref> [[Charles Lyell]] in the 1830s popularised the idea of an infinitely repeating cycle (of the [[erosion]] of rocks and the building up of [[sediment]]). Lyell believed in gradual change, and thought even Hutton gave too much credit to [[catastrophism|catastrophic changes]].
Hutton's work was published in different forms and stages: #1788. Theory of the Earth; or an investigation of the laws observable in the composition, dissolution, and restoration of land upon the Globe. ''Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh'', vol. '''1''', Part 2, pp. 209–304. #1795. ''Theory of the Earth; with proofs and illustrations''. 2 vols, Edinburgh: Creech. #1899. ''Theory of the Earth; with proofs and illustrations, vol III''. Edited by Sir Archibald Geikie. Geological Society, Burlington House, London.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category}} {{Wikiquote|Theory of the Earth}} * eBooks provided by [[Project Gutenberg]]: ** [http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/12861 ''Theory of the Earth''] (1795, vol. 1) ** [http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/14179 ''Theory of the Earth''] (1795, vol. 2)

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-212 | image = Boeing X-37B inside payload fairing before launch.jpg | image_caption = OTV-1 during encapsulation prior to maiden launch | mission_type = Demonstration | operator = [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]]/[[DARPA]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 2010-015A{{cite web |url=http://www.heavens-above.com/satinfo.aspx?satid=36514 |title=X-37B - Satellite Information |work=Heavens Above |accessdate=10 July 2013}} | SATCAT = 36514 | mission_duration = 224 days, 9 hours, 24 minutes | spacecraft_type = [[Boeing X-37|Boeing X-37B]] | manufacturer = [[Boeing]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|5400|kg|lb|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/x-37.htm |title=X-37B OTV 1, 2, 3 |work=Gunter's Space Page |first=Gunter D. |last=Krebs |accessdate=10 July 2013}} | power = Deployable solar array, batteries | launch_date = {{Start-date|22 April 2010, 23:52:00|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftOrbit.do?id=2010-015A |title=OTV 1: Launch information |work=National Space Science Data Center ''via'' NASA.gov |accessdate=10 July 2013}} | launch_rocket = [[Atlas V]] 501 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41|SLC-41]], [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] | launch_contractor = [[United Launch Alliance]] | landing_date = {{End-date|3 December 2010, 09:16:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | landing_site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]], Runway 12 | orbit_epoch = 29 November 2010, 04:26:19 UTC{{cite web |url=http://www.heavens-above.com/orbit.aspx?satid=36514 |title=X-37B - Orbit |work=Heavens Above |date=29 November 2010 |accessdate=10 July 2013}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|279|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|287|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_inclination = 39.9979° | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|6598|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_eccentricity = 0.0006 | orbit_period = 88.9 min | orbit_mean_motion = 15.97 | apsis = gee }} '''USA-212''' was the first flight of the [[Boeing]] [[Boeing X-37|X-37B]] '''Orbital Test Vehicle 1''' ('''X-37B OTV-1'''), an American unmanned robotic [[VTHL|vertical-takeoff, horizontal-landing]] (VTHL) [[spaceplane]]. It was launched aboard an [[Atlas V]] rocket from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] on 22 April 2010, and operated in [[low Earth orbit]]. Its designation is part of the [[List of USA satellites|USA series]]. The spaceplane is operated by the [[United States Air Force]], which has not revealed the specific identity of the spaceship's [[Payload (air and space craft)|payload]] for the mission. The Air Force has stated only that the spacecraft would "demonstrate various experiments and allow satellite sensors, subsystems, components, and associated technology to be transported into space and back."{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Military/2010/0420/Air-Force-to-launch-X-37-space-plane-Precursor-to-war-in-orbit |title=Air Force To Launch X-37 Space Plane: Precursor To War In Orbit? |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |last=Lubold |first=Gordon |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=23 April 2010}} ==Launch== USA-212 was launched on an Atlas V 501 rocket, tail number AV-012, from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41|Space Launch Complex 41]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]] in Florida.{{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/businesstechnology/091022-x37b-testlaunch.html |title=Air Force's Secretive Space Plane Nears Maiden Voyage |work=Space.com |last=Leonard |first=David |date=22 October 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/atlas/av012/100225x37arrival/ |title=Air Force X-37B spaceplane arrives in Florida for launch |work=Spaceflight Now |last=Clark |first=Stephen |date=25 February 2010 |accessdate=3 March 2010}} The launch, which was conducted by [[United Launch Alliance]], occurred at 23:52 [[UTC]] on 22 April 2010, placing the spacecraft into [[low Earth orbit]] for testing.{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/atlas/av012/100422launch/ |title=Atlas rocket delivers Air Force spaceplane to orbit |work=Spaceflight Now |last=Clark |first=Stephen |date=22 April 2010 |accessdate=23 April 2010}} The X-37B spacecraft was originally intended to be deployed from the payload bay of a NASA [[Space Shuttle]], but following the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|''Columbia'' accident]], it was transferred to a [[Delta II|Delta II 7920]]. It was subsequently transferred to the Atlas V following concerns over the X-37B's aerodynamic properties during launch. The launch was the first flight of the Atlas V 501 configuration,{{cite news |url=http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123201234 |title=Air Force officials launch Atlas V carrying X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle |work=AF.mil |publisher=U.S. Air Force |accessdate=23 April 2010 |date=23 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120527033023/http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123201234 |archivedate=27 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} and the first in four years to use a {{convert|5.4|m|ft|adj=on|sp=us}} [[payload fairing]].{{cite web |url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt |title=Launch Log |work=Jonathan's Space Page |last=McDowell |first=Jonathan |accessdate=23 April 2010}} Prior to the installation of the spacecraft, the Atlas rocket was moved to the launch pad and performed a [[wet dress rehearsal]] on 2 April 2010.{{cite news |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/atlas/av012/100402x37update/ |title=Air Force spaceplane is an odd bird with a twisted past |work=Spaceflight Now |last=Clark |first=Stephen |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=23 April 2010}} It was returned to the [[Vertical Integration Facility]] the next day for final assembly. The X-37 arrived at the VIF on 8 April. On 9 April, a 24-hour delay was announced. It subsequently slipped a further 24 hours after the landing of {{OV|103}} on Mission [[STS-131]] was delayed, as the [[Eastern Range]] could not have been reconfigured quickly enough to accommodate both events on the same day.{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/atlas/av012/status.html |title=Mission Status Center (OTV-1) |work=Spaceflight Now |last=Ray |first=Justin |date=23 April 2010 |accessdate=23 April 2010}} After a series of delays, it was set for 19 April 2010. On 21 April, the Atlas was rolled back out to the launch pad for launch. The launch window on 22 April opened at 23:52 UTC, and closed at 00:01 on 23 April. ==Mission== Most of the mission parameters for the USA-212 flight have not been disclosed. The vehicle is capable of being on-orbit for up to 270 days. The Air Force stated the mission time would depend on progress of the craft's experiments during orbit.{{cite news |url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/awx_04_22_2010_p0-222025.xml |title=U.S. Air Force X-37B Launched |work=[[Aviation Week]] |first=Irene |last=Klotz |date=24 April 2010}} Mission control was handled by the [[3d Space Experimentation Squadron]], [[21st Space Wing]], of the [[Air Force Space Command]] in Colorado Springs.{{cite web |url=http://www.dodlive.mil/index.php/2010/04/air-force-bloggers-roundtable-air-force-set-to-launch-first-x-37b-orbital-test-vehicle/ |title=Air Force Bloggers Roundtable: Air Force set to launch first X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle |work=DODlive.mil |publisher=U.S. Department of Defense |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=23 April 2010}} ===Observations by amateur skywatchers=== In May 2010, an amateur astronomer claimed to spot the spacecraft from his home in [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada.{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/technology/amateur-astronomers-unravel-x37-b-orbit-say-likely-use-for-deploying-spy-satellites/story-e6frfro0-1225870574214 |title=Amateur astronomers unravel X37-B orbit, say likely use for deploying spy satellites |work=News.com.au |date=24 May 2010}} Shortly after the initial observation, several more detailed observations were made by amateur skywatchers from around the world, who reported the spacecraft to have an almost circular {{convert|401|to|422|km|mi|abbr=on}} low Earth orbit with an inclination of 40°.{{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/news/secret-x-37-b-space-plane-spotted-by-amateur-astronomers-100522.html |title=Secret X-37B spaceplane spotted by amateur skywatchers |work=Space.com |first=Leonard |last=David |date=22 May 2010}} The group believed in their calculations and observations with a high degree of confidence. The spacecraft's [[ground track]] was observed to repeat every four days, which was considered indicative for a possible imaging reconnaissance mission profile.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/23/science/space/23secret.html?pagewanted=all |title=Surveillance Is Suspected as Spacecraft's Main Role |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=William J. |last=Broad |authorlink=William Broad |date=21 May 2010 |accessdate=23 May 2010}} For two weeks, starting on 29 July, the amateur skywatchers were unable to find the spacecraft in the locations they had predicted, leading them to believe it had suddenly changed its course.{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/technology/us-militarys-top-secret-x-37b-shuttle-disappears-for-two-weeks-changes-orbit/story-e6frfro0-1225909738276 |title=US military's top secret X-37B shuttle 'disappears' for two weeks, changes orbit |work=News.com.au |first=Peter |last=Farquhar |date=25 August 2010}} During the mission, the vehicle was observed to change its orbit multiple times, with a total [[delta-v]] of the first four orbit changes amounting to {{convert|102| m/s|abbr=on}}. A common characteristic of all the orbits was that the [[ground track]] nearly repeated every few days. By 12 November 2010, the orbit had been lowered to {{convert|281|by|292|km|mi|abbr=on}} with the ground track now repeating every three days (47 orbits).{{cite web |url=http://www.satobs.org/seesat/Nov-2010/0287.html|title=Updated X-37B OTV 1-1 elements|work=SatObs.org |first=Ted|last=Molczan|accessdate=25 November 2010|date=25 November 2010}} ===Altitude and ground track resonance history=== Based on data collected by [[satellite watching|amateur observers]], the following orbital characteristics were calculated by amateur skywatcher [[Ted Molczan]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Time period ! [[Periapsis]]
([[Above mean sea level|AMSL]]) ! [[Apoapsis]]

(orbits:days) |- | 2010 Apr 22 – Aug 9{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38831416/ns/technology_and_science-space/ |title=Secret X-37B space plane has changed orbit |work=MSNBC |first=Leonard |last=David |date=24 August 2010 |accessdate=5 December 2010}} | {{convert|403|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|420|km|abbr=on}} | 61:4 |- | 2010 Aug 9 – Oct 6{{cite news |url=http://www.universetoday.com/75537/secret-x-37b-space-plane-disappears-again/ |title='Secret' X-37B Space Plane Disappears Again |work=Universe Today |first=Nicholos |last=Wethington |date=11 October 2010 |accessdate=5 December 2010}} | {{convert|433|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|444|km|abbr=on}} | 91:6 |- | 2010 Oct 6 – Nov 1{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1011/30x37landing/ |title=Secret mini-shuttle due for landing as soon as Friday |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=30 November 2010 |accessdate=5 December 2010}} | {{convert|390|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|395|km|abbr=on}} | 46:3 |- | 2010 Nov 1 – Nov 12 | {{convert|315|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|328|km|abbr=on}} | 31:2 |- | 2010 Nov 12 – Dec 3 | {{convert|281|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|292|km|abbr=on}} | 47:3 |- |} ==Landing== [[File:OTV1 landing IR 20101203.png|thumb|right|Infrared view of OTV1 after landing]] After completing its mission, the X-37B was deorbited, [[atmospheric reentry|entered the atmosphere]], and landed at [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] on 3 December 2010.{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1012/03x37landing/ |title=Home again: U.S. military space plane returns to Earth |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=3 December 2010}} The X-37B is the second reusable spacecraft to perform an automated landing after returning from orbit, the first being the Soviet [[Buran (spacecraft)|Buran]] spacecraft in 1988.{{cite book |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?R=20050010181 |title=Rockets and People |volume=1 |publisher=National Aeronautics and Space Administration |series=NASA History Series |first=Boris E. |last=Chertok |editor-first=Asif A. |editor-last=Siddiqi |format=PDF |year=2005 |page=179 |id=SP-2005-4110}} ==Hypothetical mission components== As the mission of USA-212 and the X-37B program are classified, public commentary on the program is speculation. [[James Oberg]] speculated that the concurrent launch of Air Force's Hypersonic Technology Vehicle [[DARPA Falcon Project|HTV-2]] was related to the mission. Part of an X-37B's mission profile might involve a simulated enemy attack, which the X-37B should be able to detect and autonomously counteract.{{cite news |url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/aerospace/space-flight/us-air-force-launches-secret-flying-twinkie |title=U.S. Air Force Launches Secret Flying Twinkie: Military's new space plane tests unnamed powers |work=IEEE Spectrum |first=James |last=Oberg |authorlink=James Oberg |date=31 March 2010 |accessdate=25 April 2010}} HTV-2 was launched at 23:00 [[UTC]] on 22 April 2010, i.e., 52 minutes ahead of X-37B, from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] in California,{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1004/23minotaur/index.html |title=New Minotaur rocket launches on suborbital flight |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=23 April 2010 |accessdate=25 April 2010}} on a suborbital trajectory supposed to last less than 25 min.{{cite journal |url=http://www.airspacemag.com/flight-today/hypersonics.html?story=fullstory |title=Mach 20 or Bust |journal=[[Air & Space]] |first=Geoffrey |last=Little |date=1 September 2007}} The mission failed and was aborted nine minutes after launch.{{cite press release |url=http://www.darpa.mil/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=2147484133 |title=Falcon HTV-2 Launch Tests Hypersonic Vehicle Flight Capabilities |publisher=[[DARPA]] |format=PDF |first=Johanna |last=Jones |date=23 April 2010 |accessdate=5 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804194505/http://www.darpa.mil/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=2147484133 |archivedate=4 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite press release |url=http://www.darpa.mil/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=2147484134 |title=DARPA Concludes Review of Falcon HTV-2 Flight Anomaly |work=[[DARPA]] |format=PDF |date=16 November 2010 |accessdate=5 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804193948/http://www.darpa.mil/WorkArea/DownloadAsset.aspx?id=2147484134 |archivedate=4 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }} William Scott, coauthor of the techno-novel ''Counterspace: The Next Hours of World War III'' and former Rocky Mountain Bureau Chief for ''Aviation Week & Space Technology'' magazine believes that with X-37B, the Air Force might test weapon delivery from a space plane in low Earth orbit. He mentions [[Kinetic bombardment|Rods from God]] as a possible scenario.{{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/8195-air-force-mystery-37b-space-plane-fuels-speculation.html |title=Air Force's Mystery X-37B Space Plane Fuels Speculation |work=Space.com |first=Leonard |last=David |date=12 April 2010}} This hypothesis aligns with speculation that the launch of USA-212 marks the beginning of [[Militarisation of space|military operations in space]].{{cite AV media |url=http://www.cnn.com/video/?/video/tech/2010/04/23/starr.mystery.plane.cnn |title=Mystery military space plane |work=CNN.com |first=Barbara |last=Starr |type=Video |date=23 April 2010}} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} *[[2010 in spaceflight]] *[[Lockheed Martin X-33]] *[[USA-226]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{X-37B flights}} {{Orbital launches in 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Usa-212}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2010]] [[Category:DARPA]] [[Category:Satellites of the United States Air Force]] [[Category:Spacecraft which reentered in 2010]] [[Category:USA satellites]]

'''Variance-based sensitivity analysis''' (often referred to as the '''Sobol method''' or '''Sobol indices''', after [[Ilya M. Sobol]]) is a form of global [[sensitivity analysis]].<ref name="Sobol2001">Sobol,I.M. (2001), Global sensitivity indices for nonlinear mathematical models and their Monte Carlo estimates. ''MATH COMPUT SIMULAT'',55(1–3),271-280, DOI:10.1016/S0378-4754(00)00270-6</ref><ref name="Primer">Saltelli, A., Ratto, M., Andres, T., Campolongo, F., Cariboni, J., Gatelli, D. Saisana, M., and Tarantola, S., 2008, ''Global Sensitivity Analysis. The Primer'', John Wiley & Sons.</ref> Working within a [[probability|probabilistic]] framework, it decomposes the [[variance]] of the output of the model or system into fractions which can be attributed to inputs or sets of inputs. For example, given a model with two inputs and one output, one might find that 70% of the output variance is caused by the variance in the first input, 20% by the variance in the second, and 10% due to [[Interaction (statistics)|interactions]] between the two. These percentages are directly interpreted as measures of sensitivity. Variance-based measures of sensitivity are attractive because they measure sensitivity across the whole input space (i.e. it is a global method), they can deal with [[nonlinear]] responses, and they can measure the effect of interactions in non-[[Additive map|additive]] systems.<ref name="OAT">Saltelli, A., Annoni, P., 2010, How to avoid a perfunctory sensitivity analysis, ''Environmental Modeling and Software'' '''25''', 1508–1517.</ref>
==Decomposition of variance== From a [[black box]] perspective, any [[mathematical model|model]] may be viewed as a function ''Y''=''f''('''X'''), where '''X''' is a vector of ''d'' uncertain model inputs {''X''<sub>''1''</sub>, ''X''<sub>''2''</sub>, ... ''X''<sub>''d''</sub>}, and ''Y'' is a chosen univariate model output (note that this approach examines scalar model outputs, but multiple outputs can be analysed by multiple independent sensitivity analyses). Furthermore, it will be assumed that the inputs are [[Independence (probability theory)|independently]] and [[Uniform distribution (continuous)|uniformly]] distributed within the unit hypercube, i.e. <math> X_i \in [0,1] </math> for <math> i=1,2,...,d </math>. This incurs no loss of generality because any input space can be transformed onto this unit hypercube. ''f''('''X''') may be decomposed in the following way,<ref name="Sob1">Sobol’, I. (1990). Sensitivity estimates for nonlinear mathematical models. ''Matematicheskoe Modelirovanie'' '''2''', 112–118. in Russian, translated in English in Sobol’ , I. (1993). Sensitivity analysis for non-linear mathematical models. ''Mathematical Modeling & Computational Experiment (Engl. Transl.)'', 1993, '''1''', 407–414.</ref>
:<math> Y = f_0 + \sum_{i=1}^d f_i(X_i) + \sum_{i<j}^{d} f_{ij}(X_i,X_j) + \cdots + f_{1,2,\dots,d}(X_1,X_2,\dots,X_d)</math>
where ''f''<sub>0</sub> is a constant and ''f''<sub>''i''</sub> is a function of ''X''<sub>''i''</sub>, ''f''<sub>''ij''</sub> a function of ''X''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''X''<sub>''j''</sub>, etc. A condition of this decomposition is that,
:<math> \int_0^1 f_{i_1 i_2 \dots i_s}(X_{i_1},X_{i_2},\dots,X_{i_s}) dX_{k}=0, \text{ for } k = i_1,...,i_s </math>
i.e. all the terms in the functional decomposition are [[orthogonality|orthogonal]]. This leads to definitions of the terms of the functional decomposition in terms of conditional expected values,
:<math> f_0 = E(Y) </math>
:<math> f_i(X_i) = E(Y|X_i) - f_0 </math>
:<math> f_{ij}(X_i,X_j) = E(Y|X_i,X_j) - f_0 - f_i - f_j </math>
From which it can be seen that ''f''<sub>''i''</sub> is the effect of varying ''X''<sub>''i''</sub> alone (known as the [[main effect]] of ''X''<sub>''i''</sub>), and ''f''<sub>''ij''</sub> is the effect of varying ''X''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''X''<sub>''j''</sub> simultaneously, ''additional to the effect of their individual variations''. This is known as a second-order [[Interaction (statistics)|interaction]]. Higher-order terms have analogous definitions.
Now, further assuming that the ''f''('''X''') is [[Square-integrable function|square-integrable]], the functional decomposition may be squared and integrated to give,
:<math> \int_0^1 f^2(\mathbf{X}) d\mathbf{X} - f_0^2 = \sum_{s=1}^d \sum_{i_1<\dots<i_s}^d \int f_{i_1 \dots i_s}^2 dX_{i_1} \dots dX_{i_s} </math>
Notice that the left hand side is equal to the variance of ''Y'', and the terms of the right hand side are variance terms, now decomposed with respect to sets of the ''X''<sub>''i''</sub>. This finally leads to the decomposition of variance expression,
:<math> \operatorname{Var}(Y) = \sum_{i=1}^d V_i + \sum_{i<j}^{d} V_{ij} + \cdots + V_{12 \dots d}</math>
where
:<math> V_{i} = \operatorname{Var}_{X_i} \left( E_{\textbf{X}_{\sim i}} (Y \mid X_{i}) \right) </math>,
:<math> V_{ij} = \operatorname{Var}_{X_{ij}} \left( E_{\textbf{X}_{\sim ij}} \left( Y \mid X_i, X_j\right)\right) - \operatorname{V}_{i} - \operatorname{V}_{j} </math>
and so on. The ''X''<sub>~''i''</sub> notation indicates the set of all variables ''except'' ''X''<sub>''i''</sub>. The above variance decomposition shows how the variance of the model output can be decomposed into terms attributable to each input, as well as the interaction effects between them. Together, all terms sum to the total variance of the model output.
==First-order indices==
A direct variance-based measure of sensitivity ''S''<sub>''i''</sub>, called the "first-order sensitivity index", or "main effect index" is stated as follows,<ref name="Sob1" />
:<math> S_i = \frac{V_i}{\operatorname{Var}(Y)} </math>
This is the contribution to the output variance of the main effect of ''X''<sub>''i''</sub>, therefore it measures the effect of varying ''X''<sub>''i''</sub> ''alone'', but averaged over variations in other input parameters. It is standardised by the total variance to provide a fractional contribution. Higher-order interaction indices ''S''<sub>''ij''</sub>, ''S''<sub>''ijk''</sub> and so on can be formed by dividing other terms in the variance decomposition by Var(''Y''). Note that this has the implication that,
:<math> \sum_{i=1}^d S_i + \sum_{i<j}^{d} S_{ij} + \cdots + S_{12 \dots d} = 1 </math>
==Total-effect index== Using the ''S''<sub>''i''</sub>, ''S''<sub>''ij''</sub> and higher-order indices given above, one can build a picture of the importance of each variable in determining the output variance. However, when the number of variables is large, this requires the evaluation of 2<sup>''d''</sup>-1 indices, which can be too computationally demanding. For this reason, a measure known as the "Total-effect index" or "Total-order index", ''S''<sub>''Ti''</sub>, is used.<ref>Homma, T. and A. Saltelli (1996). Importance measures in global sensitivity analysis of nonlinear models. ''Reliability Engineering and System Safety'', '''52''', 1–17.</ref> This measures the contribution to the output variance of ''X''<sub>''i''</sub>, ''including'' all variance caused by its interactions, of any order, with any other input variables. It is given as,
:<math> S_{Ti} = \frac{E_{\textbf{X}_{\sim i}} \left(\operatorname{Var}_{X_i} (Y \mid \mathbf{X}_{\sim i}) \right)}{\operatorname{Var}(Y)} = 1 - \frac{\operatorname{Var}_{\textbf{X}_{\sim i}} \left(E_{X_i} (Y \mid \mathbf{X}_{\sim i}) \right)}{\operatorname{Var}(Y)} </math>
Note that unlike the ''S''<sub>''i''</sub>,
:<math> \sum_{i=1}^d S_{Ti} \geq 1 </math>
due to the fact that the interaction effect between e.g. ''X''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''X''<sub>''j''</sub> is counted in both ''S''<sub>''Ti''</sub> ''and'' ''S''<sub>''Tj''</sub> In fact, the sum of the ''S''<sub>''Ti''</sub> will only be equal to 1 when the model is purely [[Additive map|additive]].
==Calculation of indices== For analytically tractable functions, the indices above may be calculated analytically by evaluating the integrals in the decomposition. However, in the vast majority of cases they are estimated – this is usually done by the [[Monte Carlo method]].
===Sampling sequences=== [[File:Construction of ABi matrices in monte carlo estimation of sensitivity indices.png|thumb | right | 500px | An example of construction of '''A'''<sub>B</sub><sup>''i''</sup> matrices with ''d''=3 and ''N''=4.]] The Monte Carlo approach involves generating a sequence of randomly distributed points inside the unit hypercube (strictly speaking these will be [[Pseudorandom number generator|pseudorandom]]). In practice, it is common to substitute random sequences with [[low-discrepancy sequence]]s to improve the efficiency of the estimators. This is then known as the [[quasi-Monte Carlo method]]. Some low-discrepancy sequences commonly used in sensitivity analysis include the [[Sobol sequence]] and the [[Latin hypercube sampling|Latin hypercube]] design.
===Procedure=== To calculate the indices using the (quasi) Monte Carlo method, the following steps are used:<ref name="Sobol2001" /><ref name="Primer" />
# Generate an ''N''×2''d'' sample matrix, i.e. each row is a sample point in the hyperspace of 2''d'' dimensions. This should be done with respect to the probability distributions of the input variables. # Use the first ''d'' columns of the matrix as matrix '''A''', and the remaining ''d'' columns as matrix '''B'''. This effectively gives two independent samples of ''N'' points in the ''d''-dimensional unit hypercube. # Build ''d'' further ''N''×''d'' matrices '''A'''<sub>B</sub><sup>''i''</sup>, for ''i'' = 1,2,...,d, such that the ''i''th column of '''A'''<sub>B</sub><sup>''i''</sup> is equal to the ''i''th column of '''B''', and the remaining columns are from '''A'''. # The '''A''', '''B''', and the ''d'' '''A'''<sub>B</sub><sup>''i''</sup> matrices in total specify ''N''(''d''+2) points in the input space (one for each row). Run the model at each design point in the '''A''', '''B''', and '''A'''<sub>B</sub><sup>''i''</sup> matrices, giving a total of ''N''(''d''+2) model evaluations – the corresponding f('''A'''), f('''B''') and f('''A'''<sub>B</sub><sup>''i''</sup>) values. # Calculate the sensitivity indices using the estimators below.
The accuracy of the estimators is of course dependent on ''N''. The value of ''N'' can be chosen by sequentially adding points and calculating the indices until the estimated values reach some acceptable convergence. For this reason, when using low-discrepancy sequences, it can be advantageous to use those that allow sequential addition of points (such as the Sobol sequence), as compared to those that do not (such as Latin hypercube sequences).
===Estimators=== There are a number of possible Monte Carlo estimators available for both indices. Two that are currently in general use are,<ref name="Sobol2001" /><ref>Andrea Saltelli, Paola Annoni, Ivano Azzini, Francesca Campolongo, Marco Ratto, and Stefano Tarantola. Variance based sensitivity analysis of model output. Design and estimator for the total sensitivity index. ''Computer Physics Communications'', 181(2):259{270, 2010</ref>
: <math> \operatorname{Var}_{X_i}(E_{\mathbf{X}_{\sim i}}(Y|X_i)) \approx { \frac {1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} f \left ( \mathbf{B} \right )_{j} \left ( f \left ( \mathbf{A}^i_B \right )_{j} - f \left ( \mathbf{A} \right )_{j} \right ) } </math>
and
: <math> E_{\mathbf{X}_{\sim i}}\left(\operatorname{Var}_{X_i}\left(Y \mid \mathbf{X}_{\sim i} \right) \right) \approx {\frac {1}{2N}\sum_{j=1}^{N} \left( f \left ( \mathbf{A} \right )_{j} - f \left (\mathbf{A}^i_B \right )_{j}\right )^2 } </math>
for the estimation of the ''S''<sub>''i''</sub> and the ''S''<sub>''Ti''</sub> respectively.
===Computational expense=== For the estimation of the ''S''<sub>''i''</sub> and the ''S''<sub>''Ti''</sub> for all input variables, ''N''(''d''+2) model runs are required. Since ''N'' is often of the order of hundreds or thousands of runs, computational expense can quickly become a problem when the model takes a significant amount of time for a single run. In such cases, there are a number of techniques available to reduce the computational cost of estimating sensitivity indices, such as [[Sensitivity analysis#Emulators|emulators]], [[Sensitivity analysis#High-Dimensional Model Representations (HDMR)|HDMR]] and [[Sensitivity analysis#Fourier Amplitude Sensitivity Test (FAST)|FAST]].
